title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Today’s Mission
We’ll explore how Linear Programming (LP) helps make critical decisions in different areas of a business.

Marketing: How to design a cost-effective survey.
Finance: How to invest millions for maximum return.
Operations: How to schedule a workforce to meet production goals.


Today, we move from the “how” of LP to the “why.” We’ll see that the same structured thinking—defining variables, an objective, and constraints—can be applied to solve very different kinds of business puzzles.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Marketing Application: MSI Research
The Scenario: Market Survey Inc. (MSI) needs to conduct 1000 door-to-door interviews for a new product. They want to do it as cheaply as possible, but they have a lot of rules to follow.
The Puzzle: How do you plan the interviews to meet all the requirements at the minimum cost? This is a classic resource allocation problem perfect for LP.

Think of this like planning a big event on a tight budget. You have to invite specific groups of people (the constraints) and want to spend as little as possible (the objective).

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
MSI: Breaking Down the Problem
First, let’s identify the core components of our LP model.


1. Decisions (Variables) We need to decide how many interviews to conduct in each category.

\(DC\): Daytime, with Children
\(EC\): Evening, with Children
\(DNC\): Daytime, No Children
\(ENC\): Evening, No Children


2. Objective (The Goal) Minimize the total survey cost.



Interview Type
Cost

$18

$20



Minimize Cost: 20DC + 25EC + 18DNC + 20ENC

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
MSI: The Rules (Constraints)
These are the rules MSI must follow, translated into math.







Rule in Plain English
Mathematical Constraint




1. Conduct exactly 1000 interviews in total.
\(DC+EC+DNC+ENC = 1000\)


2. At least 400 households with children.
\(DC+EC \geq 400\)


3. At least 400 households without children.
\(DNC+ENC \geq 400\)


4. Evening interviews must be \(\geq\) daytime.
\(EC+ENC \geq DC+DNC\)


5. \(\geq 40\%\) of “with children” interviews in evening.
\(EC \geq 0.4(DC+EC)\)


6. \(\geq 60\%\) of “no children” interviews in evening.
\(ENC \geq 0.6(DNC+ENC)\)




Each rule becomes a line in our LP model. Notice how we rearrange some constraints (like #4, #5, #6) to have all the variables on one side (-DC + EC - DNC + ENC >= 0) before putting them into a solver.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Financial Application: Winslow Portfolio
The Scenario: Winslow Savings has $20 million to invest over the next 4 months. They want to maximize their interest earnings.
The Puzzle: How should they allocate their money each month between different investment options to get the highest return, while making sure they have enough cash for a big project later? This is a multi-period planning problem.

Think of this like a 4-level video game. In each level (month), you invest resources. Your earnings from one level carry over to the next. You need a strategy to maximize your score (interest) while making sure you have enough power-ups ($10M) for the final boss fight (the building venture).

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Winslow: Variables and Objective
This model is dynamic, so our variables need to track investments in each month i (where i=1, 2, 3, 4).

\(G_i\): New investment in Government bonds in month i. (2% return over 2 months)
\(C_i\): New investment in Construction loans in month i. (6% return over 3 months)
\(L_i\): Liquid funds invested locally in month i. (0.75% return per month)

Objective: Maximize Total Interest \[
\text{Max } 0.02(G_1+...+G_4) + 0.06(C_1+...+C_4) + 0.0075(L_1+...+L_4)
\]

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Winslow: Cash Flow Constraints
This is the tricky part. The money available to invest each month depends on what investments from previous months have matured.

Month 1: Start with $20M.

\(G_1 + C_1 + L_1 = 20,000,000\)

Month 2: Money available is the cash (\(L_1\)) from Month 1 plus its interest.

\(G_2 + C_2 + L_2 = 1.0075 L_1\)

Month 3: Money comes from bonds from Month 1 (\(G_1\)) and cash from Month 2 (\(L_2\)) maturing.

\(G_3 + C_3 + L_3 = 1.02 G_1 + 1.0075 L_2\)

Month 4: Money from loans from M1 (\(C_1\)), bonds from M2 (\(G_2\)), and cash from M3 (\(L_3\)).

\(G_4 + C_4 + L_4 = 1.06 C_1 + 1.02 G_2 + 1.0075 L_3\)

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Winslow: Other Constraints & Solution
There are a few more critical rules to follow.







Constraint
Explanation




\(1.06C_2 + 1.02G_3 + 1.0075L_4 \ge 10,000,000\)
Must have 10M cash available at start of Month 5.


\(G_1+G_2 \le 8,000,000\), etc.
Total Gov’t bonds held at any time must not exceed 8M.


\(C_1+C_2+C_3 \le 8,000,000\), etc.
Total Const. loans held at any time must not exceed 8M.



The Optimal Solution: The solver provides a detailed month-by-month investment plan that results in a maximum interest of $1,429,214.

The full solution table is complex, but the key takeaway is that LP can map out this entire 4-month strategy, balancing risk (investment limits) and reward (interest) to meet all of the bank’s goals perfectly.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Operations Application: NWC Workforce
The Scenario: National Wing Company (NWC) has a contract to produce a specific number of airplane wings each month for three months. They need to manage their workforce to meet these targets.
The Puzzle: How can NWC hire, train, and assign workers each month to meet the production schedule at the minimum possible payroll cost?

This is like managing a sports team for a championship run. You have veterans (producers), rookies (apprentices), and prospects (recruits). Some veterans need to step back from playing to coach (trainers). You need to find the right mix each month to win all your games (meet production targets) while staying under the salary cap (minimizing cost).

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
NWC: The Workforce Flow
A key part of this problem is understanding how the workforce changes over time. A new recruit isn’t immediately productive.

A Recruit needs one month of training to become an Apprentice.
An Apprentice needs one more month to become a fully Qualified Worker.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
NWC: Variables and Objective
Let’s define our decision variables and goal for April (i=1), May (i=2), and June (i=3).

\(P_i\): Number of Producers in month i
\(T_i\): Number of Trainers in month i
\(A_i\): Number of Apprentices in month i
\(R_i\): Number of Recruits in month i

Objective: Minimize Total Wage Cost \[
\text{Min } 3000P_1 + 3300T_1 + ... + 3000P_3 + 2600A_3
\]

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
NWC: Key Constraints
This model links months together.

Production Targets: The number of wings produced each month must meet the contract. \(0.6P_1 + 0.3T_1 + 0.05R_1 \ge 20\) (April’s production)
Workforce Balance: The number of qualified workers flows from one month to the next. \(P_2 + T_2 = P_1 + T_1\) (Qualified workers don’t disappear) \(A_2 = R_1\) (April’s recruits become May’s apprentices)
Training Capacity: Each trainer can handle two recruits. \(2T_1 \ge R_1\)
Boundary Conditions: Start with 100 workers, end with at least 140. \(P_1 + T_1 = 100\) \(P_3 + A_3 \ge 140\)

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Outline

Problem Solving and Decision Making
Models of Cost, Revenue, and Profit
Introduction to Linear Programming
Problem Formulation
A Simple Maximization and Minimization Problem


Welcome! Today, we’ll explore how businesses use mathematical models to make better decisions. We’ll start with basic concepts like cost and profit, and then move on to a powerful tool called Linear Programming.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
What is a Mathematical Model?
A model is a simplified representation of a real-world situation. We use it to understand problems and test solutions before applying them in real life.


Deterministic Model

All inputs are known and fixed.
No uncertainty involved.
Example: Calculating the area of a room. You know the length and width for sure.


Stochastic (Probabilistic) Model

Some inputs are uncertain or random.
Involves probabilities.
Example: Forecasting next week’s sales. It might be affected by weather, holidays, or other random events.



Think of a deterministic model like a recipe: if you follow the instructions exactly, you get the same cake every time. A stochastic model is more like predicting the weather; you have good information, but you can’t be 100% certain. In business, we often have to choose between a simple, cheap model and a complex, expensive one. Sometimes, simpler is better!

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Example 1: Austin Auto Auction
Let’s build a model to help an auctioneer set a starting bid for a used car.
The Goal: Set the starting bid (B) at 70% of the predicted final winning bid.
The Logic:

Start with the car’s original price (P).
Deduct for age (A): $800 per year.
Deduct for mileage (M): $0.025 per mile.


This is a classic example of a descriptive model. It takes known information and uses a formula to describe a situation—in this case, a car’s estimated value.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Example 1: Building the Model
First, let’s write an equation for the expected winning bid:
\[
\text{Expected Bid} = P - 800A - 0.025M
\]
Now, we can build the full model for the starting bid (B), which is 70% of that value:
\[
\begin{aligned}
B &= 0.7 \times (\text{Expected Winning Bid}) \\
B &= 0.7 \times (P - 800A - 0.025M) \\
B &= 0.7P - 560A - 0.0175M
\end{aligned}
\]
This is our final model! It’s a simple linear equation.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Example 1: Using the Model
Question: A car is 4 years old with 60,000 miles. Its original price was $12,500. What should the starting bid be?
Answer: We just plug the numbers into our model.

P = $12,500
A = 4 years
M = 60,000 miles

\[
\begin{aligned}
B &= 0.7(12,500) - 560(4) - 0.0175(60,000) \\
B &= 8750 - 2240 - 1050 \\
B &= \$5,460
\end{aligned}
\]
The auctioneer should set the starting bid at $5,460.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Example 1: What Are We Assuming?
Every model has assumptions. It’s important to know what they are!
What assumptions does this model make?

Only three factors matter: Original price, age, and mileage. It ignores things like the car’s condition, color, brand reputation, or if it’s a rare model.
Value loss is linear: It assumes a car loses exactly $800 in value every year and $0.025 every mile, forever. In reality, this isn’t true. A very old car could have a negative starting bid with this model, which doesn’t make sense!


This is a crucial lesson in modeling: models simplify reality. They are useful tools, but not perfect reflections of the world. Always question the assumptions behind a model.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Example 2: Ponderosa Development Corp.
This company builds and sells one style of house. Let’s model its costs, revenue, and profit to find its break-even point—the number of houses it needs to sell just to cover its costs.


Key Financials (per house, per month):

Selling Price: $115,000
Variable Costs (per house):

Land: $55,000
Materials: $28,000
Labor: $20,000
Sales Commission: $2,000
Total Variable Cost: $105,000

Fixed Costs (per month):

Office lease, utilities, etc.: $5,000
Employee Salaries: $35,000
Total Fixed Cost: $40,000



Monthly Salaries

Here we distinguish between two types of costs. Variable costs change with the number of houses built (like lumber). Fixed costs stay the same each month whether they sell 1 house or 10 houses (like the president’s salary).

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Example 2: The Profit Model
Let ‘x’ be the number of houses sold in a month.
1. Revenue Function r(x): How much money comes in? \[
r(x) = 115,000x
\]
2. Cost Function c(x): How much money goes out? \[
c(x) = \underbrace{105,000x}_{\text{Variable Costs}} + \underbrace{40,000}_{\text{Fixed Costs}}
\]
3. Profit Function p(x): Revenue minus Cost. \[
\begin{aligned}
p(x) &= r(x) - c(x) \\
p(x) &= 115,000x - (105,000x + 40,000) \\
p(x) &= 10,000x - 40,000
\end{aligned}
\]

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Example 2: Break-Even and Profit
What is the break-even point? Break-even is when profit is zero, or when Revenue = Cost. \[
\begin{aligned}
115,000x &= 105,000x + 40,000 \\
10,000x &= 40,000 \\
x &= 4
\end{aligned}
\] Ponderosa needs to sell 4 houses per month to break even.
What is the profit if they sell 12 houses? \[
p(12) = 10,000(12) - 40,000 = \$80,000
\] They would make an $80,000 profit.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Example 2: Visualizing the Break-Even Point
A graph makes this crystal clear. Let’s plot the Cost and Revenue functions.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Introduction to Linear Programming (LP)
Linear Programming is a powerful mathematical tool used to find the best possible outcome (like maximum profit or minimum cost) in a given situation with certain limits or constraints.

Objective: The goal you want to maximize (e.g., profit) or minimize (e.g., cost).
Constraints: The rules or limitations you must follow (e.g., limited budget, time, or materials).
Feasible Solution: Any solution that satisfies all the constraints.
Optimal Solution: The feasible solution that gives the best possible value for the objective function.


Think of it like planning a diet. Your objective is to minimize calorie intake. Your constraints are that you must get enough protein, vitamins, and minerals, and you only have a certain budget for groceries. LP helps you find the perfect meal plan that meets all your needs while keeping calories as low as possible.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
The “Linear” in Linear Programming
So, what makes it “linear”?

Linear Functions: Each variable is simple (like x or y, not \(x^2\) or \(\sqrt{y}\)) and is multiplied by a constant.

Linear: 3A + 5B
Not Linear: 3A² + 5/B

Linear Constraints: These are linear functions restricted by inequalities or equalities.

Linear: 2x + 3y ≤ 50
Linear: A = 100


This linearity makes the problems solvable with efficient methods.

title: Management Decision Tools
Management Decision Tools
text:
LP Example 3: M&D Chemicals (Minimization)
Problem: M&D Chemicals needs to produce two products, A and B, at the lowest possible cost while meeting certain production demands.

Production Target: Total production of A and B must be at least 350 gallons.
Customer Order: Must produce at least 125 gallons of A.
Resource Limit: Only 600 hours of processing time are available.

Product A takes 2 hours/gallon.
Product B takes 1 hour/gallon.

Costs:

Product A costs $2/gallon.
Product B costs $3/gallon.


Objective: Minimize total production cost.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Example 3: M&D Chemicals Formulation
Let A = number of gallons of product A, and B = number of gallons of product B.
Minimize Cost: \[
\text{Min } 2A + 3B
\]
Subject to (s.t.): \[
\begin{array}{rll}
A &\ge 125 & \text{(Customer Demand)} \\
A + B &\ge 350 & \text{(Total Production)} \\
2A + B &\le 600 & \text{(Processing Time)} \\
A, B &\ge 0 & \text{(Non-negativity)}
\end{array}
\]
Optimal Solution: Produce 250 gallons of A and 100 gallons of B for a minimum cost of $800.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Example 3: Visualizing the M&D Solution
The valid production plans are in the shaded “Feasible Region”. The model finds the corner point in this region with the lowest cost.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
LP Example 4: Iron Works, Inc. (Maximization)
Problem: Iron Works makes two products from steel. They want to maximize their profit for the month.

Resource Limit: 2000 pounds of steel available.

Product 1 needs 2 lbs of steel.
Product 2 needs 3 lbs of steel.

Contract: Must make at least 60 units of Product 1.
Production Limit: Can make at most 720 units of Product 2.
Profits:

Product 1: $100 per unit.
Product 2: $200 per unit.


Objective: Maximize total profit.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Example 4: Iron Works Formulation
Let \(x_1\) = number of units of Product 1, and \(x_2\) = number of units of Product 2.
Maximize Profit: \[
\text{Max } 100x_1 + 200x_2
\]
Subject to (s.t.): \[
\begin{array}{rll}
2x_1 + 3x_2 &\le 2000 & \text{(Steel limit)} \\
x_1 &\ge 60 & \text{(Contract)} \\
x_2 &\le 720 & \text{(Production limit)} \\
x_1, x_2 &\ge 0 & \text{(Non-negativity)}
\end{array}
\]
Optimal Solution: From solver analysis, the best plan is to make 60 units of Product 1 and 626.67 units of Product 2.

title: Management Decision Tools
section: Example 4: Visualizing the Iron Works Solution
text:
Example 4: Visualizing the Iron Works Solution
Again, we can map out the “Feasible Region”. The goal is to find the corner point that gives the highest profit.

title: Bullying
text:
What is Bullying?
Bullying is more than just a conflict or disagreement. It’s a pattern of aggressive behavior. It involves certain key characteristics.

title: Bullying
text:
Defining Bullying
Key Characteristics

Imbalance of Power:

The aggressor has more power, real or perceived.
This could be physical strength, social status, or access to embarrassing information.

Repetition:

Bullying behaviors occur multiple times.
It’s not an isolated incident but a pattern over time.

Intent to Harm:

The primary goal is to cause distress, fear, or damage.
This harm can be physical, emotional, social, or reputational.



Highlight that all three elements usually need to be present for an interaction to be classified as bullying. An isolated unkind act, while wrong, isn’t necessarily bullying. The power imbalance is crucial, as it makes it difficult for the victim to defend themselves effectively.

title: Bullying
text:
Types of Bullying (1)
1. Physical Bullying

Direct harm: Hitting, kicking, pushing, tripping.
Property damage: Destroying belongings, stealing.
Intimidation: Threatening gestures, invading personal space.

2. Verbal Bullying

Words as weapons: Teasing, name-calling, insults.
Threats: Expressing intent to harm or cause fear.
Derogatory remarks: Spreading rumors, prejudiced comments.

title: Bullying
text:
Types of Bullying (2)
3. Social/Relational Bullying

Exclusion: Deliberately leaving someone out of activities.
Rumor spreading: Damaging reputation, gossiping.
Manipulation: Damaging friendships, influencing others to dislike someone.

4. Cyberbullying

Online harassment: Mean messages, hurtful posts, spreading rumors online.
Impersonation: Pretending to be someone else to cause trouble.
Non-consensual sharing: Distributing private images or information without permission.


Emphasize that cyberbullying is particularly insidious because it can reach victims 24/7 and content can be permanent. Also, mention that these types can often overlap. For example, verbal bullying can easily turn into cyberbullying if comments are posted online.

title: Bullying
text:
Why Does Bullying Happen?

Individual Factors:

Insecurity or low self-esteem in the bully.
Lack of empathy or understanding of others’ feelings.
Personal history of being bullied or witnessing violence.

Social & Environmental Factors:

Peer pressure and desire for social dominance.
Lack of effective supervision by adults.
Cultural norms that tolerate aggression.
Stressful home environments or lack of emotional support.

title: Bullying
text:
Impact of Bullying on Victims (1)

Mental and Emotional Health:

Anxiety, depression, and increased stress levels.
Low self-esteem, feelings of worthlessness.
Increased risk of self-harm and suicidal thoughts.

Physical Health:

Sleep disturbances, headaches, stomach aches.
Weakened immune system due to chronic stress.

title: Bullying
text:
Impact of Bullying on Victims (2)

Academic Performance:

Difficulty concentrating, lower grades.
Increased absenteeism or school refusal.

Social Development:

Social isolation, difficulty forming trusting relationships.
Fear of social situations, withdrawal from activities.








Note


The long-term psychological impact can be as devastating, if not more so, than immediate physical harm. Support is crucial!




Emphasize the serious public health implications of bullying. It’s not just a “childhood phase” but a significant contributor to mental health issues that can persist into adulthood.

title: Bullying
text:
Impact of Bullying on Perpetrators
While victims suffer visible harm, bullies themselves also face significant negative consequences.

Behavioral Issues:

Increased risk of substance abuse, and criminal behavior later in life.
Difficulty maintaining healthy adult relationships.

Social Repercussions:

Negative perceptions from peers, teachers, and adults.
Potential for social isolation or association with other aggressive individuals.

Academic & Professional Setbacks:

Disciplinary actions, suspension, expulsion from school.
Difficulties finding employment due to behavioral history.



It’s important to understand that bullying is often a cry for help or a learned behavior. Addressing the bully’s issues, rather than just punishing them, is essential for breaking the cycle.

title: Bullying
text:
Signs Someone is Being Bullied (1)
Behavioral Changes

Sudden withdrawal from social activities or interests.
Changes in eating or sleeping patterns (e.g., nightmares, loss of appetite).
Increased irritability, unexplained outbursts.
Avoiding school or specific places.

Emotional Distress

Appearing anxious, sad, or depressed.
Frequent crying spells or mood swings.
Expressing feelings of helplessness or hopelessness.

title: Bullying
text:
Signs Someone is Being Bullied (2)
Physical Signs

Unexplained bruises, cuts, or scratches.
Missing or damaged personal belongings.
Frequent reasons to avoid school or class.

Academic Decline

Drop in grades or sudden disinterest in schoolwork.
Difficulty concentrating in class.
Reluctance to participate in class discussions.


Stress the importance of observation and empathy. Not all signs will be present, and some might be subtle. These are general indicators, and any significant change in behavior warrants concern and a gentle approach.

title: Bullying
text:
How to Avoid Bullying
Building Resilience and Safety

Boost Self-Esteem:

Focus on strengths, pursue hobbies, celebrate small victories.
Confidence can make you less of a target.

Develop Assertiveness:

Learn to say “no” firmly and clearly.
Maintain eye contact and use a steady voice.

Build a Strong Support Network:

Surround yourself with positive friends and trusted adults.
Strength in numbers, and people to confide in.



Emphasize that “avoiding bullying” does not mean the victim is at fault. These are strategies for self-protection and empowerment, not blame. Also, discuss online safety: never share personal information, report harmful content immediately, and block bullies.

title: Bullying
text:
What to Do If Bullied (1)
Taking Action and Seeking Help

Speak Up:

Tell a trusted adult: parent, teacher, counselor, coach.
Don’t keep it a secret; secrets give power to the bully.

Document Everything:

Keep records of incidents: dates, times, locations, what happened, who was involved.
Save messages, screenshots if it’s cyberbullying.

title: Bullying
text:
What to Do If Bullied (2)
Taking Action and Seeking Help

Stay Calm & Walk Away:

Reacting emotionally can sometimes fuel the bully.
If possible, remove yourself from the situation.

Practice Self-Care:

Engage in activities you enjoy, get enough rest, eat well.
It’s important to prioritize your well-being.



Reiterate the message: “It’s not your fault, and you do not deserve to be bullied.” Provide actionable steps and reassure students that seeking help is a sign of strength, not weakness. Discuss school policies and reporting mechanisms briefly.

title: Bullying
section: How to Stop the Bully Cycle (1)
text:
How to Stop the Bully Cycle (1)
Collective Responsibility

Students: Intervention:

Don’t be a passive observer; your inaction can empower the bully.
Support the victim, distract the bully, or report the incident.

Students: Promote Empathy & Kindness:

Educate and encourage understanding of others’ feelings.
Organize campaigns for kindness and inclusion.

title: Bullying
section: How to Stop the Bully Cycle (2)
text:
How to Stop the Bully Cycle (2)
Collective Responsibility

Schools: Establish Clear Policies:

Schools and institutions need explicit anti-bullying policies.
Consistent enforcement and consequences are crucial.

Schools and Teachers: Open Communication:

Foster environments where students feel safe to report.
Adults must listen actively and take concerns seriously.



Emphasize the power of the bystander. Changing bystander behavior is one of the most effective ways to reduce bullying, as bullies often thrive on the perceived approval or silence of others.

title: Bullying
text:
Let’s Stop Bullying
Fostering a Culture of Respect
Let’s build communities where everyone feels safe, valued, and respected.
\[
\text{Empathy} + \text{Respect} \times \text{Action} = \text{Safer Community}
\]

“Stand Up, Speak Out”:

Your voice has power. Use it to defend others and challenge bullying.

“Kindness is Contagious”:

One act of kindness can inspire many more, creating a ripple effect.

“Celebrate Differences”:

Diversity enriches us all; embracing our unique qualities makes our community stronger.

“We Are All In This Together”:

A safe environment is a shared responsibility. Support each other.



The LaTeX formula is a symbolic representation, not a literal mathematical equation, designed to be impactful. Focus on the core messages and how they translate into daily actions and mindset shifts.

title: Bullying
text:
Call to Action
Be the Change

Educate Yourself: Continue to learn about bullying and its impact.
Intervene Safely: If you see bullying, intervene if safe, or report it to an adult.
Be an Ally: Support those who are being bullied; let them know they’re not alone.
Promote Inclusivity: Welcome new people, stand against exclusion, and champion diversity.
Speak Up: If you or someone you know is being bullied, reach out. Help is available.


End with a strong, empowering message. Provide specific, actionable steps tailored to undergraduate students. Maybe suggest campus resources like counseling services, student support offices, or specific anti-bullying initiatives.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years — Wisdom for a Lifetime
text:
Wisdom from Edward Packard (© 2025)
Prepared by Imron Rosyadi for students.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years — Wisdom for a Lifetime
text:
Introduction: Learning Life’s Big Lessons

The author, Edward Packard, looks back at age ninety.
He realized he “went off the rails” often, and luck helped him survive.
Many mistakes could have been avoided if he’d grasped a few principles sooner.
This presentation shares those 9 things, hoping you learn them earlier!


Start by making it relatable: everyone makes mistakes, but learning from others can save you trouble. Packard offers a lifetime of wisdom distilled into actionable advice.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years — Wisdom for a Lifetime
section: 1) Be Self-Constituted: Build Your Inner Compass
text:
1) Be Self-Constituted: Build Your Inner Compass

What it means: Being “consistent, unified, and whole” – having integrity.
It’s about setting your own “virtuous moral framework” to guide your actions.
Think of good values like kindness, honesty, and fairness.
Without it, you’re “ruled by a heap of impulses”—a bit of a mess.



How your moral framework works:





graph TD
    A[Virtuous Moral Framework] --> B{Decision Making};
    B --> C[Consistent Actions];
    C --> D[Integrity and Self-Assurance];
    E[Impulses] --x B;
    style A fill:#DCEFFB,stroke:#333,stroke-width:1px













Note


Think of a raft on a river:
You’re poling, trying to steer the best course. Your “self-constitution” is your strong paddle and clear direction.





Real-world connection: Imagine facing peer pressure to cheat. If you’re self-constituted with a moral framework of honesty, you’ll naturally decline because it aligns with your core principles, not just fear of getting caught. Kant’s “universal law” suggests acting only on principles you’d want everyone to follow.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years — Wisdom for a Lifetime
section: 2) Keep Awake and Aware: Don’t Sleepwalk Through Life
text:
2) Keep Awake and Aware: Don’t Sleepwalk Through Life

Sleepwalking: Doing things without thinking about their purpose or consequences.
It affects judgment, even in smart people or leaders making big decisions (like leaders before WWI).
Avoiding “mental lethargy” means confronting uncomfortable facts instead of ignoring them.



Being Awake & Aware

Fully present in the moment.
Understand why you’re doing something.
Consider effects on self and others.
Makes you “a buddha” (Thich Nhat Hanh: understanding, compassionate, loving).


Sleepwalking

Autopilot mode.
Ignoring unpleasant facts.
Can lead to catastrophic outcomes.
Failure to weigh risks.








Warning


Habitual sleepwalking can lead to acting (or not acting) in ways that cause obvious future problems if you were truly awake.




Contemporary example: Mindlessly scrolling social media for hours without a purpose is a form of sleepwalking. Being awake means setting an intention, like “I will spend 15 minutes checking news, then do something productive.” Think about how easily we can just react instead of choose.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years
section: 3) Consider what others may be thinking and feeling
text:
3) Consider what others may be thinking and feeling
Main idea: Use empathy and “theory of mind” to guess how others will react.
Why it matters: Thoughtless comments can hurt people or ruin chances to connect.
Short example: Packard once said a joke that offended an older man because he didn’t consider the man’s feelings.

Describe “theory of mind” as imagining someone else’s thoughts and feelings. Ask students to think of times a careless comment caused trouble and how it could be avoided.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years — Wisdom for a Lifetime
section: 3) Consider What Others May Be Thinking and Feeling
text:
3) Consider What Others May Be Thinking and Feeling

Tip


Before speaking or acting, pause for a few seconds. Ask yourself: 1. How would I feel if someone said/did this to me? 2. What might be going on in their mind right now? This small pause can prevent big regrets.




Classic example: The author talks about making a “witty” remark about someone’s boat that he now realizes was crude and offensive. He thought it would impress, but he didn’t consider how it would land for the other person.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years
section: 4) Make happiness your default state of mind
text:
4) Make happiness your default state of mind
Main idea: Be the kind of person who chooses compassion and respect every day so happiness becomes normal.
Why it matters: Small daily habits and attitudes shape long-term mood more than rare big events.
Quote idea: “More important than being loved is to love.”






Note


Try focusing on kindness each day; it often makes you and others happier.




Explain that the Dalai Lama suggests love and compassion lead to happiness regardless of religion. Mention practical habits: gratitude, helping others, and steady respect for people.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years — Wisdom for a Lifetime
section: 5) Seek an Eternal Perspective: Look Beyond Yourself
text:
5) Seek an Eternal Perspective: Look Beyond Yourself

What it is: Expanding your view beyond your ego to include others, nature, and the entire cosmos.
Philosopher Spinoza found joy and calmness (equanimity) in understanding the natural order.
This perspective is like “compassion without attachment” – you’re active, but not controlled by fear or desire for specific outcomes.



Benefits of an Eternal Perspective

Reduces anger, envy, pride.
Emotional disengagement from specific outcomes can bring inner peace.
You can stay “alive, in action” without being swept away by desires or fears.
See the beauty in the journey, not just the destination (like the snow leopard trek).


Potential Challenges (and replies from text)

“Will life be colorless?” “Won’t it drain excitement?”

Reply: Not necessarily. The expedition itself (the looking at nature, the walking) was wonderful, even without seeing the snow leopard. The monk’s “Isn’t that wonderful!” when they found nothing showed release from attachment.

“Is it at odds with self-interest?”

Reply: Spinoza would say it’s a necessary condition for a truly fulfilling life, bringing equanimity and joy.




Modern thinking: Think about climate change or conservation. An “eternal perspective” acknowledges our tiny place in a vast, ongoing system and encourages actions that benefit future generations or the planet, not just immediate personal gain.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years — Wisdom for a Lifetime
section: 6) Guard Against Self-Deception: Be Honest With Yourself
text:
6) Guard Against Self-Deception: Be Honest With Yourself

Self-deception: When your beliefs and decisions are skewed by biased emotions, wishful thinking, or subconscious justifications.
Confirmation bias: A common example where you favor information that supports what you already believe, ignoring anything that contradicts it.
Even brilliant people fall prey to it, using their intellect to justify flawed conclusions.







Warning


“Certitude is not the test of certainty.” – Oliver Wendell Holmes, Jr. Feeling sure about something doesn’t mean you’re right.




Francis Bacon: The mind “pulls everything else into agreement with and support” for its favored views.
Daniel Kahneman: Strong beliefs are often sustained by a “community of likeminded believers.”

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years — Wisdom for a Lifetime
section: 6) Guard Against Self-Deception: Be Honest With Yourself
text:
6) Guard Against Self-Deception: Be Honest With Yourself
Interactive Demo: See how we can selectively ‘confirm’ a belief


All observations: [4.59, -4.62, -0.87, -1.65, 6.05, 5.15, 8.38, -3.7, 1.33, -4.55, -1.72, 2.58, -4.6, -2.02, 4.75, 3.17, -1.69, 3.84, 7.14, -4.9]

Evidence confirming belief (positive outcomes): [4.59, 6.05, 5.15, 8.38, 1.33, 2.58, 4.75, 3.17, 3.84, 7.14]
  (Count: 10 out of 20 total)




Explaining the demo: This simple code shows how easily we can zero in on data that supports our existing ideas (confirming_evidence), potentially ignoring other data. This is what confirmation bias does in real life – leading us to believe we’re right because we only “see” what proves it.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years — Wisdom for a Lifetime
section: 7) How to Confront Mortality: Facing Life’s End
text:
7) How to Confront Mortality: Facing Life’s End

Stoics (ancient Greeks/Romans): Contemplate death often to not be shocked when it comes.
Spinoza’s approach (author’s preference): Find peace and self-control by gaining an “eternal perspective” through knowledge.
Rejects supernatural claims; focuses on the natural world.



Famous Views on Mortality

George Eliot: “I try to delight in the sunshine that will be when I shall never see it any more.” Focus on what endures beyond your individual life.
Bertrand Russell: Overcome fear of death by making your “interests gradually wider and more impersonal,” merging with “universal life.”


Fearlessness & Acceptance

Katharine Hepburn: “I look forward to oblivion.” A brave acceptance of the end.
Michel de Montaigne: “I want death to find me planting my cabbages, neither worrying about it, nor about the unfinished gardening.” Live fully, without preoccupation.








Important


Confronting mortality isn’t about being gloomy; it’s about shifting your focus from the “small bundle of facts that make our own personality” to something larger, which can bring calmness and richer participation in life.




Personal reflection: How can thinking about your own limited time make you value what you do each day more? This isn’t about dread, but about thoughtful living and prioritizing.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years
section: 8) What an outsized role is played by luck
text:
8) What an outsized role is played by luck
Main idea: Many things about our lives come from luck — birth, chance opportunities, and random events.
Why it matters: If luck matters, we should be more humble when we succeed and more kind to people who struggle.
Modern example: Some rich people became wealthy by luck and then influence rules to stay rich.

Point out that recognizing luck encourages generosity and compassion. Ask students to name one thing in their lives they think was due to luck.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years — Wisdom for a Lifetime
section: 9) To Consider What You Have at the Moment
text:
9) To Consider What You Have at the Moment

Be dynamic and take initiative, but also mindful.
Sometimes, it’s vital to pause and appreciate what’s right in front of you.
We often don’t truly value things until they are lost.

\[\text{Value Lost} > \text{Value Possessed}\]
This isn’t a strict formula, but a common human tendency.

Shakespeare (Much Ado About Nothing):
That what we have we prize not to the worth Whiles we enjoy it, but being lacked and lost, Why, then we rack the value, then we find The virtue that possession would not show us While it was ours.







Tip


Take a moment each day to consciously acknowledge and appreciate something you have right now – a friendship, a quiet moment, a skill you possess.




Contemporary example: Think about how easily we take our smartphones for granted. It’s a powerful tool, but if it’s lost, its “virtue” (its utility and convenience) becomes incredibly apparent. Appreciating things proactively can deepen life’s richness.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years — Wisdom for a Lifetime
section: Quick Recap: Nine Lessons for a Better Life
text:
Quick Recap: Nine Lessons for a Better Life


1. Build a strong moral character.
2. Stay awake and aware.
3. Think about others’ feelings.
4. Choose happiness as your default.
5. See the bigger picture (eternal perspective).

6. Watch out for self-deception.
7. Understand and face mortality.
8. Recognize the role of luck.
9. Appreciate what you have now.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years — Wisdom for a Lifetime
section: Applying These Lessons to Your Life
text:
Applying These Lessons to Your Life

These aren’t just ideas; they’re practices.
Pick one lesson that resonated most with you today.
Try to apply it in a small way this week.
Even small changes, consistently done, can make a big difference over time.


Encourage students to choose one point and try to implement it directly. Ask them to reflect on a specific situation where this lesson could be applied in their daily lives (e.g., before sending a text, giving a compliment, making a decision about their future).

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Outline

Introduction to Sensitivity Analysis
Interpreting Computer Solutions
Range of Optimality (for Objective Coefficients)
Reduced Cost (for Decision Variables)
Range of Feasibility (for RHS Constraints)
Shadow Price (for Constraints)
Simultaneous Changes (The 100% Rule)


In our last session, we learned how to find the single best solution. But the real world is messy and numbers change. Today, we’ll learn how to analyze what happens to our solution when costs, profits, or resources change. This is called Sensitivity Analysis.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Introduction to Sensitivity Analysis
Sensitivity analysis (or post-optimality analysis) is the study of how changes in a linear programming model’s coefficients affect the optimal solution.
It helps us answer “what-if” questions like:

What if our profit per unit for Product A increases? Will we make more of it?
What if the cost of a raw material goes down? How does that change our total cost?
What if we get 10 more hours of labor available? How much more profit can we make?

This is crucial for managers who work in a dynamic environment where estimates are not always perfect.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Interpreting a Sensitivity Report
When we solve an LP problem using software like Excel Solver, it gives us the optimal solution and a “Sensitivity Report”. This report is our main tool for this analysis.


Variables Section This part tells us about our decision variables (e.g., how much of a product to make).

Final Value: The optimal quantity to produce.
Objective Coefficient: The original profit/cost per unit.
Allowable Increase/Decrease: This defines the Range of Optimality.
Reduced Cost: The “penalty” for forcing a non-optimal variable into the solution.


Constraints Section This part tells us about our limitations (e.g., resources, demand).

Final Value: The amount of the resource used (LHS).
Constraint R.H. Side: The original limit.
Allowable Increase/Decrease: This defines the Range of Feasibility.
Shadow Price: The value of one extra unit of a resource.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Example: Olympic Bike Co. Problem
Olympic Bike Co. is making two new bike frames: Deluxe and Professional.

Objective: Maximize weekly profit.
Profit: $10/Deluxe, $15/Professional.
Resources:

100 lbs of Aluminum Alloy
80 lbs of Steel Alloy





Frame
Aluminum (lbs)
Steel (lbs)




Deluxe
2
3


Professional
4
2



LP Solution: Produce 15 Deluxe and 17.5 Professional frames for a max profit of $412.50.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Range of Optimality
The Range of Optimality is the range a profit or cost coefficient can change without changing the optimal production plan (the Final Values).
Let’s look at the report for Olympic Bike:



Variable
Final Value
Objective Coeff
Allowable Increase
Allowable Decrease




Deluxe (D)
15
10
12.5
2.5


Professional (P)
17.5
15
5
8.33



For the Deluxe frame, the profit is $10. The allowable increase is $12.5 and decrease is $2.5.
So, the Range of Optimality for Deluxe profit is:
[$10 - $2.5, $10 + $12.5] ⇒ [$7.5, $22.5]

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Range of Optimality: “What If?”
Question 1: The profit on Deluxe frames increases to $20. Is the solution (15 Deluxe, 17.5 Professional) still optimal?
Answer: Yes. $20 is within the range [$7.5, $22.5].
The production plan does not change.
However, the total profit will increase: \[
\text{New Profit} = (\mathbf{\$20} \times 15) + (\$15 \times 17.5) = \$300 + \$262.50 = \mathbf{\$562.50}
\]
Question 2: The profit on Deluxe frames drops to $6. Does the solution change?
Answer: Yes, it might. $6 is outside the range [$7.5, $22.5]. The current production plan is no longer guaranteed to be optimal. We would need to re-solve the LP to find the new best plan.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Reduced Cost
Reduced Cost applies to variables whose optimal value is zero.
It tells you how much the variable’s profit/cost coefficient must improve (increase for profit, decrease for cost) before it becomes a good idea to include it in the solution.

If a variable is already in the optimal solution (Final Value > 0), its reduced cost is always 0.
If a variable has a Final Value of 0, its reduced cost is the “penalty” for forcing one unit of it into the solution.


Imagine you have a choice between making product A (profit $5) and product B (profit $3). The model tells you to only make A. The “reduced cost” for B might be $2. This means you would lose $2 in overall profit for every unit of B you force into the production plan. The profit on B would need to increase by at least $2 (to over $5) before it’s worth making.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Shadow Price
The Shadow Price (or Dual Value) of a constraint is one of the most powerful concepts in LP.

It is the amount the objective function value will improve for every one-unit increase in the Right-Hand Side (RHS) of that constraint.


It’s the “price” you’d be willing to pay for one more unit of a scarce resource.
A constraint is binding if it’s fully used (LHS = RHS). Binding constraints have non-zero shadow prices.
A constraint is non-binding if there is slack. Non-binding constraints always have a shadow price of 0.


Think about it: if you have leftover aluminum alloy (a non-binding constraint), how much would you pay for one more pound? Nothing! You haven’t even used what you have. But if you’ve used up all your steel (a binding constraint), one extra pound would let you make more bikes and more profit. The shadow price tells you exactly how much more profit.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Range of Feasibility
The Range of Feasibility is the range the RHS of a constraint can change while the shadow price remains valid.
Let’s look at the constraints report for Olympic Bike:



Constraint
Final Value (LHS)
Shadow Price
Constraint R.H. Side
Allowable Increase

For Aluminum, the shadow price is $3.125. This means for every extra pound of aluminum we get, our total profit will increase by $3.125.
This is only true within the Range of Feasibility: [100 - 46.67, 100 + 60] ⇒ [53.33, 160].

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Slack & Surplus Variables
To understand binding vs. non-binding constraints, it helps to know about slack and surplus variables. Software uses them behind the scenes to convert inequalities into standard equations.

Slack Variables (for ≤ constraints): Represents the amount of an unused resource. 2x + 3y ≤ 100 becomes 2x + 3y + s₁ = 100. If s₁ > 0, the constraint is non-binding (there is slack).
Surplus Variables (for ≥ constraints): Represents the amount produced above a minimum requirement. A + B ≥ 350 becomes A + B - s₂ = 350. If s₂ > 0, the constraint is non-binding (we produced more than the minimum).

Key idea: if slack or surplus is 0, the constraint is binding.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
Simultaneous Changes: The 100% Rule
What if multiple things change at once? We can use the 100% Rule.

The 100% Rule states that the solution (and shadow prices) will remain valid as long as the sum of the percentages of the changes (relative to their maximum allowable changes) does not exceed 100%.

Formula: \[
\sum_{i} \frac{|\text{Actual Change}_i|}{\text{Allowable Change}_i} \le 1
\]
This rule applies separately to Objective Coefficients (testing the Range of Optimality) and RHS values (testing the Range of Feasibility).

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
100% Rule Example: Objective Coefficients
Question: At Olympic Bike, what if the profit on Deluxe frames rises to $16 and the profit on Professional frames rises to $17 at the same time? Will the solution (15 D, 17.5 P) still be optimal?

Analyze change in Deluxe profit:

Actual change: $16 - $10 = $6.
Allowable increase: $12.5.
Percentage of change: \(6 / 12.5 = 48\%\).

Analyze change in Professional profit:

Actual change: $17 - $15 = $2.
Allowable increase: $5.
Percentage of change: \(2 / 5 = 40\%\).

Sum the percentages:

\(48\% + 40\% = 88\%\).


Conclusion: Since 88% is less than 100%, the optimal solution will not change. The production plan remains 15 Deluxe and 17.5 Professional frames.

title: Management Decision Tools
text:
100% Rule Example: RHS Values
Question: For M&D Chemicals (our minimization problem from last time), what if the minimum total production (Constraint 2) is decreased by 25 gallons, and the available processing time (Constraint 3) is increased by 30 hours?
Sensitivity Report Snippet:



Constraint
Change
Allowable Change

↓ 25
↓ 50
4

↑ 30
↑ 100
-1




Analyze change in Total Production RHS:

Percentage of change: \(25 / 50 = 50\%\).

Analyze change in Processing Time RHS:

Percentage of change: \(30 / 100 = 30\%\).

Sum the percentages:

\(50\% + 30\% = 80\%\).


Conclusion: Since 80% < 100%, the shadow prices are still valid. We can calculate the change in total cost: \[
\begin{aligned}
\text{Change in Cost} &= (-25 \times \text{ShadowPrice}_2) + (30 \times \text{ShadowPrice}_3) \\
&= (-25 \times 4) + (30 \times -1) \\
&= -100 - 30 = -\mathbf{\$130}
\end{aligned}
\] The total cost will decrease by $130. New Cost = $800 - $130 = $670.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years
section: Life Lessons from Edward Packard’s “Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years”
text:
Life Lessons from Edward Packard’s “Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years”
Overview:

Quick, easy-to-read summary of the nine lessons Packard shares in his memoir.
Language is simple so high school students can understand.
Includes diagrams, a small interactive chart, math-style idea, and speaker notes.


This slide deck turns Packard’s nine life lessons into short, clear slides for classroom use. Use the speaker notes to expand on examples and guide discussion.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years
text:
Roadmap of the Nine Lessons
What we will cover:

Be self-constituted.
Keep awake and aware.
Consider what others are thinking and feeling.
Make happiness your default.
Seek an eternal perspective.
Guard against self-deception.
How to confront mortality.
Recognize the outsized role of luck.
Notice and value what you have now.


Point quickly to each lesson so students know the structure. Mention that examples come from history, literature, and modern life.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years
text:
1) Be self-constituted
Main idea: Build a stable, honest character and stick to it.
Why it matters: If you have clear values, you are less likely to be pushed around or make harmful choices.
Short example: Huckleberry Finn tries to do what feels right for everyone on the raft, showing kindness and fairness.

Talk about what “self-constituted” means: being guided by your chosen moral rules, not just impulses. Point out the risk: someone can be self-constituted but selfish, so the values must be kind and fair.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years
text:
2) Keep awake and aware
Main idea: Don’t “sleepwalk” through life; pay attention to what you do and why you do it.
Why it matters: Important decisions made without awareness can cause big harm.
Real case: Leaders before World War I acted without truly understanding the risks, and that led to disaster.

Give a simple definition of “sleepwalking” as acting without thinking about causes and consequences. Encourage students to pause before big choices and check their reasons.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years
text:
5) Seek an eternal perspective
Main idea: Try to see life from a broader viewpoint — beyond small, intense worries.
Why it matters: A wide view can bring calm and let you enjoy the present without being crushed by failure or desire.
Example: A monk who didn’t see failure in not spotting a snow leopard, but found the whole trip wonderful.


Stoicism

Think about death to reduce fear.
Practice self-control.


Spinoza-style

Seek compassion without attachment.
Find joy by understanding nature and life.



Use the column slide to compare two ways of gaining calm: Stoic training and broader, compassionate views. Ask students: Which fits you more, preparing for hard events or expanding what you care about?

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years
text:
6) Guard against self-deception
Main idea: Be careful that your feelings or wishes don’t trick you into believing false things.
Why it matters: Smart people can fool themselves by only noticing facts that match what they already believe.
Warning sign: If you only read or listen to people who agree with you, you may be trapped by confirmation bias.

Give a quick activity: ask students to list one belief they feel sure about and then find one strong argument against it. Explain that checking yourself helps better decisions and relationships.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years
text:
7) How to confront mortality
Main idea: Thinking about death calmly helps you live better and be less afraid.
Why it matters: When you accept that life ends, you can focus on what matters now and act kindly.
Examples: Montaigne and Katherine Hepburn were calm about dying and focused on simple pleasures like gardening.

Emphasize that the goal is not morbid worry but a healthy acceptance that encourages meaning. Suggest small practices: imagine what you’d want remembered about you, or write a short letter to family.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years
section: 9) Consider what you have at the moment
text:
9) Consider what you have at the moment
Main idea: Notice and appreciate what you own and who you are with right now.
Why it matters: People often only notice good things after they’re gone.
Shakespeare line: We prize not what we have while we enjoy it, but when it’s lost we find its true value.

Encourage a short classroom exercise: have students write down three things they often take for granted. Discuss how gratitude practices can improve mood and relationships.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years
section: Quick “math” idea about Luck and Effort
text:
Quick “math” idea about Luck and Effort
\[ \text{Outcome} = \text{Skill} + \text{Effort} + \text{Luck} \]
Interpretation: Work hard and get better skills, but remember luck still helps a lot. Use this to stay humble and to help others when you can.

Explain the equation as a simple way to think about success. Stress that it doesn’t remove the value of effort, but it adds perspective.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years
section: Interactive chart: Emphasis on each lesson
text:
Interactive chart: Emphasis on each lesson


                            
                                            



This bar chart shows a simple score for how strongly each lesson is emphasized in the book. Invite students to suggest different scores and explain why.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years
text:
Short classroom activities

Pair-share a time you “sleepwalked” and what you’d change now.
List one habit to build kindness and one way to check your own bias.
Write a 1-minute gratitude note for something you usually take for granted.


These activities are quick and help students practice the lessons. Use them to spark discussion or reflective writing.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years
text:
Final Takeaways

Build a steady character and stick to kind values.
Stay awake, imagine other minds, and be compassionate.
Make happiness a habit, accept death calmly, and know luck matters.
Notice what you have now and be thankful.







Note


Small daily choices add up more than big dramatic ones.




Wrap up by encouraging students to pick one lesson to try for a week. Tell them to notice any changes in their mood or relationships.

title: Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years
text:
Sources and Further Reading

Edward Packard, Nine Things I Learned in Ninety Years (2025).
Christine Korsgaard, Self-Constitution (2009).
Thich Nhat Hanh, The Art of Living (2017).
